Create Your First App
true

This tutorial walks you through creating your first packaged app. Packaged apps are structured similarly to extensions. You need to produce a zip file of all your assets for your applications that you will then upload to the Chrome Web Store.

API Samples: Want to play with the code? Check out the hello-world sample.

The packaged app zip file contains these components:

  • The manifest tells Chrome about your app, what it is, how to launch it and the extra permissions that you require.
  • The background script is used to create the event page responsible for managing the app life cycle.
  • All code must be included in the package. This includes HTML, JS, CSS and Native Client modules.
  • The icons are required for the launcher and visibility in the user's system.

    • Step 1: Create the manifest

    First ceate your manifest.json file (Manifest Files describes this manifest in detail): 

    {
  "name": "Hello World!",
  "description": "My first packaged app.",
  "manifest_version": 2,
  "version": "0.1",
  "app": {
    "background": {
      "scripts": ["background.js"]
    }
  },
  "permissions": ["experimental", "appWindow"],
  "icons": { "16": "icon-16.png", "128": "icon-128.png" }
}

    Important: Packaged apps must use manifest version 2.

    Step 2: Create the background script

    Next create a new file called background.js with the following content: 

    chrome.experimental.app.onLaunched.addListener(function() {
  chrome.appWindow.create('window.html', {
    'width': 400,
    'height': 500
  });
});

    In the above sample code, the 'width' and 'height' control the size of the app window. Your background script may contain additional listeners, windows, post messages, and launch data, all of which are used by the event page to manage the app.

    Step 3: Create a window page

    Create your window.html file: 

    <!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
  </head>
  <body>
    <div>Hello, world!</div>
  </body>
</html>

    Step 4: Create the icons

    Copy these icons to your app folder:

    • icon-16.png
    • icon-128.png

    Step 5: Launch your app

    Enable flags

    You should enable experimental APIs:

    • Go to chrome://flags.
    • Find "Experimental Extension APIs", and click its "Enable" link.
    • Restart Chrome.

      • Load your app

      To load your app, bring up the apps and extensions management page by clicking the wrench icon and choosing Tools > Extensions.

      Make sure the Developer mode checkbox has been selected.

      Click the Load unpacked extension button, navigate to your app's folder and click OK.

      Open new tab and launch

      Once you've loaded your app, open a New Tab page and click on your new app icon.
